abstractText: In response to the Sergeant First Class Heath Robinson Honoring our Promise to Address Comprehensive Toxics (PACT) Act being signed into law, several research groups in Colorado organized the First Annual PACT Act Research Symposium for Veteran Health. The 2-day symposium was interested in research relevant to military exposures with a primary focus on respiratory and mental health. Information on the PACT Act, data sources in the Department of Veteran Affairs and DOD, and research opportunities at the Veteran Affairs were presented. The morning session centered on respiratory health, highlighting research conducted over the last two decades regarding deployment-related respiratory diseases. Despite the high prevalence of mental health disorders among Veterans, information presented during the afternoon sessions on mental health highlighted the dearth of research to date regarding psychological health and military-related exposures. Policymakers, clinicians, and researchers were encouraged to adopt a life-course approach when conceptualizing physical and psychological exposures. On the second day of meetings, a smaller group of participants discussed next steps in military exposure research, as well as priorities for future research. Per the latter, recommendations for future research were made regarding the need for more precise exposure characterization, longitudinal data collection, and efforts to increase understanding regarding disease pathogenesis, as well as the impact of exposures across multiple organs. sections.heading: INTRODUCTION
sections.text:

pits, anthropogenic particulate matter (PM), fuels, chemical agents, depleted uranium, and/or radiation. Health effects are variable and can affect multiple organ systems associated with many conditions (e.g., respiratory diseases, mental health diseases, cancers, neurodegenerative disorders, and chronic multisymptom illness [e.g., Gulf War Illness]).
The Sergeant First Class Health Robinson Honoring our Promise to Address Comprehensive Toxins (PACT) Act was signed into U.S. law on August 10, 2022 (PACT Act, public law 117–168). The PACT Act includes significant expansion of benefits and associated services to U.S. Veterans exposed to toxicants including expanded eligibility to Veteran Affairs (VA) health care. Over 20 additional presumptive conditions were introduced related to exposure to burn pits, Agent Orange, and other toxic exposures, as well as additional presumptive exposure locations for Agent Orange and radiation. In addition, per the PACT Act, the Veteran Health Administration is required to provide toxic exposure screening to every Veteran to identify cases and increase knowledge. Notably, the PACT Act also expands research, education, and treatment regarding toxic exposures.
In an effort to increase understanding regarding the current state of science and clinical practice relevant to the PACT Act, the Rocky Mountain Regional VA Medical Center (Aurora, CO) hosted the First Annual PACT Act Research Symposium for Veteran Health, May 3 and 4, 2023. The event was organized by the team at the VA Rocky Mountain Mental Illness Research Education and Clinical Center and partners in the Rocky Mountain Regional VA Research Service and at the University of Colorado, Anschutz Medical Campus. The symposium focused on the research relevant to deployed military exposures with a morning session dedicated to respiratory health and an afternoon session on mental health. Speakers also discussed the PACT Act, VA data availability, current and planned clinical practices, and opportunities for engaging in research at the VA (see Table I for speaker information on May 3). Nearly 200 people participated in the hybrid (webinar, in person) event and 25 participating researchers gathered on May 4 to discuss the next steps. Full details on the event, including presentation slides and videos of the presentations, can be found online (https://www.mirecc.va.gov/visn19/pact_ act_symposium/index.asp).

sections.heading: RESPIRATORY HEALTH
sections.text:
The primary emphasis of the respiratory health session was Southwest Asia Deployment-Related Respiratory Diseases (DRRD). Two decades of post-9/11 DRRD research (epidemiologic, clinical, and translational) were summarized, along with data regarding health outcomes from toxic exposures in the First Gulf War Era Cohort Study. Current areas of DRRD research included respiratory health effects from jet fuel and polyaromatic hydrocarbon exposure; inflammatory effects of PM on human airway epithelial cells and alveolar macrophage gene expression; and identification of proteomic, metabolomic, and epigenetic biomarkers of burn pit emissions and respirable PM exposures. Mechanistic studies are
laying the groundwork for emerging DRRD treatment trials, such as a study of L-citrulline supplementation in Veterans with suboptimally controlled deployment-related asthma (ClinicalTrials.gov identifier: NCT05259904).
Several respiratory research themes emerged that currently require additional research: (1) better exposure characterization1; (2) DRRD clinical and longitudinal outcomes; (3) disease pathogenesis to inform evidence-based treatments; and (4) integrated multiorgan and multidisciplinary collaboration. Along with current efforts to characterize military exposures (e.g., Airborne Hazards and Open Burn Pit Registry), additional approaches to understanding individual exposures are needed that can be incorporated into the VA standardized electronic medical record. Retrospective exposure characterization could be explored through biomarkers (e.g., omics, inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, or Raman spectroscopy), research that is now being expanded in animal and artificial intelligence models. To better understand disease pathogenesis, the bidirectional interactions between lung–brain, lung–gut, and gut–brain axes are areas of particular interest. Other research priorities identified by the group included the following: (1) risk factors, endotypes, and mechanisms of deployment-related asthma; (2) distal small airway inflammation leading to bronchiolitis, emphysema, and hyperinflation2; (3) exercise limitation and mitochondrial dysfunction3; (4) exposure and epigenetic effects of DDRD; (5) epidemiological trends and outcomes in those with DDRD; and (6) effects on mental health, aging, and neurodegenerative disease. There was enthusiasm for research on the integration of multiorgan system outcomes and effect modifiers secondary to military occupational exposures. Several participants endorsed a life course and an integrated exposome approach to account for inhalational hazards across multiple time points, environmental conditions (e.g., climate and pollutants), life events (e.g., trauma and stress), individual characteristics (e.g., gender and race), and individual lifestyle choices (e.g., diet, exercise, and substance use).4

sections.heading: MENTAL HEALTH
sections.text:
Several areas of focus and needs emerged from the session on mental health. Specifically, these included the following: (1) the extensive mental health burden on Veterans (one study suggested that up to 41% of Operation Iraqi Freedom/Operation Enduring Freedom/Operation New Dawn) had a positive screen or diagnosis for a mental health condition5; (2) exposures to emotional (e.g., seeing people killed or hurt) and/or physical (e.g., toxicants, physical injury, air pollution/ozone,6 and sand/dust7) stressors may increase the risk for new-onset mental health conditions and suicide risk8; and (3) acute and chronic systemic inflammation may result in neuroinflammation, including activation of microglia and astrocytes, and ultimately contribute to negative physical and psychological health-related outcomes. Overall, the importance of adopting a life-course approach (i.e., accumulation of risk over time) was also emphasized.9

A combination of presentations on basic, translational, and clinical research supported the assertion that a bench-tobedside and back approach is needed to expedite our understanding regarding associations between exposures, potential mechanisms (including inflammation), and mental health outcomes. Such efforts would be expected to provide the foundational work necessary to develop innovative treatment approaches. For example, a proof-of-concept model of regional air pollution combined with longitudinal mental health surveys and disease outcomes may enable an increased understanding of the connections between pollutants and health outcomes. A bench approach through mouse modeling10 was also presented to identify mechanisms by which exposures and stress may interact to affect disease risk, severity, and prognosis. Finally, resources for collaboration, funding, and combined efforts with pre- and post-deployment support were discussed to improve outcomes while increasing the quality of life for current Veterans through rapid translation of new findings. The post-symposium meeting focused on identifying research priorities with a focus on inflammation (or the inflammatory process) as a key mechanism of action. There was a consensus regarding the importance of designing studies to evaluate the impact of exposures across organ systems (e.g., lung–brain axis) with the goal of highlighting novel treatment targets and strategies (e.g., anti-inflammatory agents). Discussion also focused on the potential importance of targeting mitochondrial functioning and exercise rehabilitation. There was a widespread agreement regarding the need for efforts focused on identifying differences in individual

A potential near-term solution included increased holistic screening and sample collection (e.g., plasma) at the point of clinical care. Specifically, this would require asking “the right questions” at the “right times” (e.g., age at, duration of, and nature of exposures over time). Other key areas for future work included multiorgan assessment and targeted metabolomics with a focus on priority exposures and multiparameter outcomes.

sections.heading: FOCUS AREAS AND NEXT STEPS
sections.text:
The First Annual PACT Act Research Symposium for Veteran Health discussion was focused on key priority areas as outlined in the PACT Act and the mission and goals of the Military Exposure Research Program, i.e., “to advance military exposure assessments and to understand the effects of military exposures on Veterans’ health outcomes to inform care and policy.”11 Much of the discussion was on military exposures, defined as “toxic agents, singularly or in combination, incurred through military service (Deployment, Occupation, or Garrison).”11 In-depth discussion was on PM 2.5 μm (PM2.5) and burn pit exposures leading to negative health outcomes, defined as “changes in health status such as any measurable disease, disability, injury, syndrome, symptom, biological or subclinical marker, organ system function or health state arising from military exposures.”11 Given the nature of PM2.5 and burn pit exposures, discussion centered around the bronchopulmonary system and brain health– related conditions, “including chronic multi-symptom illness, traumatic brain injury, post-traumatic stress disorder, depression, episodes of psychosis, schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, suicide attempts, and suicide deaths.” (PACT Act, public law 117–168. Sec. 507).
Interests in the relationships between toxic exposures, respiratory diseases, and mental health outcomes were discussed in terms of the growing recognition regarding a lung–gut–brain axis influencing the immune reactivity of the central nervous system compartment, including the resident innate immune cells of the brain (e.g., microglia).12 Chronic multisymptom illness may involve signaling within the bidirectional lung–brain–gut axis.13 Understanding of multiorgan, multisymptom outcomes of toxic exposurerelated illnesses will benefit from a multidisciplinary and collaborative research team approach.
Existing resources, such as the longitudinal samples within the Military and Veteran Microbiome: Consortium for Research and Education, which includes longitudinal (i.e., every 6 months) sampling of skin, oral, and gut microbiomes in association with extensive assessment of physical and mental health outcomes, or targeted expansion of these resources may prove to be useful for future studies. A major challenge moving forward is to determine with precision the influence of time-limited toxic exposures (e.g., over a period of 6–12 months), in the context of preexisting vulnerabilities,14 and potential differential outcomes of multiple, repeated toxic
exposures and their interaction with other physical and psychosocial stressor exposures on health outcomes over the lifespan. Of particular interest in this regard are the impacts of military exposures on peripheral immune signaling, inflammation, and neuroinflammation, which are exaggerated with advanced age.15 A final step will be identifying multitargeted interventions with the potential to influence immune signaling and inappropriate disease-related inflammation, as well as minimizing negative health outcomes across the lifespan.

sections.heading: CONCLUSION
sections.text: The 2-day event highlighted the importance of interdisciplinary efforts to increase the understanding regarding military toxicant exposures. Indeed, participants in the event recognized other individuals and groups (e.g., Defense Health Agency, other DoD agencies, and international partners) that should be included in future events. Additional research must include individuals from diverse disciplines, biological (e.g., inflammation and gut–lung–brain axis) and biobehavioral/biopsychosocial (e.g., life events, mental health, and physical health). A funded multidisciplinary research consortium could accelerate the progress of bench-to-bedside translational efforts that could provide central biorepositories of samples and data and infrastructure with shared research personnel and resources to help break down traditional silos.
